messageBody:
Staaleund,

I don't think I'm answering all of your questions, so feel free to
re-ask if I miss something.

On 11/14/06, staaleund <staaleund@...> wrote:
> Both the XML and ehcache implementation implements the same
> interfaces, so I would like to write my test once, and then run them
> over both implementations.

The "Parameterized Test Case" pattern (ask Google or the book JUnit
recipes) is your friend here. It's built into JUnit 4 as the
Parameterized custom runner.

> I also have a small problem that fetching some off the Objects I am
> testing over XML is an expensive operation. I currently fetch objects
> in the setUp method, but that gets run before each test method. What
> is the prefered way to fetch this object once and reuse in all the
> tests? The object I am currently working on having this problem is
> immutable, so test won't modify its content.

Can you use JUnit 4? Then you can use a @BeforeClass annotation. If
not, look at the TestSetup decorator in JUnit 3.x.

> Finally, the XML test of course requires an URL to fetch data from.
> This is dependent on the test environment. What is the normal way to
> set up and read such parameters for a test?

How do you set up and read such parameters in your application? Are
they hard-coded, or read from an external file?

Thanks,

David
